item.title: UK scholarships for Afghan students paused
item.description: The government says the situation in Afghanistan means the British Embassy in Kabul cannot finalise plans.

item.title: Covid: 16 and 17-year-olds in England to be offered jab by 23 August
item.description: Those in England will be offered a jab or the chance to book one by 23 August, the government says.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Parents upset at jabs wait for high-risk children
item.description: Some families are struggling to get vaccines for vulnerable teens, nearly a month after they became eligible.

item.title: GCSE results 2021: Record passes and top grades
item.description: Record high GCSE grades in a second year of exams disrupted by the pandemic.

item.title: Covid: Air purifier and UV light pilot to combat school virus spread
item.description: The project, which includes 30 schools in Bradford, will look at air quality and pupil absences.

item.title: A-levels: Warning over private and state school gap
item.description: The former school recovery tsar warns of growing educational inequality as a result of the pandemic.

item.title: A-level results 2021: Top grades reach record high
item.description: The second year of results after cancelled exams sees the highest level of A* and A grades at A-level.

item.title: Scottish results day: Record high for A grades as pass rate falls
item.description: Pupils' pass rates are still well above pre-pandemic levels after formal exams were cancelled for the second year.

item.title: A-level results: Record rate of top grades for NI students
item.description: More than half of A-level entries in Northern Ireland have been awarded the top A* and A grades.

item.title: Nearly half achieve top A-level grades in Wales
item.description: A total of 48.3% of A-level grades are A and A* in Wales, which is hailed a "remarkable achievement".

item.title: A-level results: Students have been treated fairly - watchdog
item.description: The head of the exams regulator defends the system for deciding grades ahead of A-level and GCSE results day.

item.title: A-levels 2021: What you need to know about this year's results
item.description: For the second year running, pupils in England, Wales and Northern Ireland have not taken the exams.

item.title: Exams 2021: 'Will they take our Covid grades seriously?'
item.description: It's been a stressful few months for the thousands of young people waiting for their exam results.

item.title: Will Scotland go back to traditional school exams?
item.description: Will Scottish school pupils be studying for traditional exams in 2022, or have things changed for good?

item.title: Cash prize jackpot offered for double-jabbed students
item.description: A university hopes to boost Covid jab take-up among students by offering 10 Â£5,000 cash prizes.

item.title: GCSE results 2021: How were grades decided?
item.description: Teachers have decided their pupils' grades after Covid cancelled exams for a second year.

item.title: GCSEs 2021: The 9-1 grading system explained
item.description: Teenagers will receive their GCSE results on 12 August.

item.title: Parents' fears over sexting and abuse among teenagers
item.description: A mother and a father reveal their shock at learning of their children's experiences of online sex.

item.title: Zoomtown-on-Sea? The lure of a new life on the coast
item.description: Remote working meant the Lancaster family could live anywhere - they found their sea view in Scarborough.

item.title: 'I thought rape isn't something that happens to men'
item.description: Support charities say male victims of sexual assault sometimes feel their experiences don't count.

item.title: Will my child get free school meals this summer?
item.description: A year on from Marcus Rashford's successful campaign, what is the current situation?

item.title: Students: âUni definitely not good value this yearâ
item.description: Students are angry at paying full fees with so little in-person teaching, says report.

item.title: Self-isolating students in end-of-tenancy 'nightmare'
item.description: What happens if a housemate tests positive for Covid just as you were about to move out?

item.title: Poorer white pupils 'let down and neglected'
item.description: White pupils from low income families are falling behind "every step of the way", an education committee says.

item.title: Covid-19: School proms hit by continuing lockdown restrictions
item.description: Pupils' plans to celebrate with their friends have been hit by continuing lockdown restrictions.

item.title: Child labour in Uganda: The hidden costs of Covid
item.description: When all Uganda's schools closed due to the pandemic, nine-year-old Teddy joined her mother mining for gold.

item.title: Should schoolchildren still have to self-isolate?
item.description: More than a quarter of a million children are absent from school in the UK because of coronavirus.

item.title: Contaminated blood inquiry: The school where dozens of pupils died
item.description: Ex-pupils caught up in the infected blood scandal decades ago are giving evidence at an inquiry.

item.title: 'I play all the instruments in my Irish music band'
item.description: CaitrÃ­ona Lagan is a 15-year-old All-Ireland champion musician who plays five instruments.

item.title: 'Only way you'll get to Oxford is on a bus'
item.description: Social mobility campaigner Sir Peter Lampl worries about the lack of fair opportunity for young people.

item.title: Williamson wants to scrap bubbles to keep pupils in school
item.description: With more pupils sent home from school in England, there are calls for a different approach to Covid cases.

item.title: More pupils sent home as Covid disruption soars
item.description: Rapid increase in pupils out of school in England as changes expected for self-isolation rules.

item.title: Free school lunches for all children in P4 and P5 in Scotland
item.description: All pupils in P4 will be entitled to a school meal from August, while P5s will be offered lunches by January.

item.title: School catch-up tsar resigns over lack of funding
item.description: England's school recovery commissioner Sir Kevan Collins quits, saying the funding "falls far short".

item.title: Boris Johnson promises more school catch-up cash in 'damp squib' row
item.description: Boris Johnson defends Â£1.4bn tutoring school catch-up plan after heads left "hugely disappointed".

item.title: Face masks no longer required in classrooms
item.description: Face coverings will not be needed in England's secondary classrooms from 17 May, says the prime minister.

item.title: Covid: Poor pupils fall further behind in maths
item.description: The gap between poor pupils and their classmates is unlikely to narrow without intervention, researchers say.

item.title: Coronavirus testing: How to do a lateral flow test at home
item.description: Coronavirus lateral flow tests are free and provide a quick result within 30 minutes. But how do you do one?

item.title: School 'feels alive' after children's return
item.description: The BBC visited one school in Lincolnshire to see how its staff and children were coping on week one.

item.title: First day back at school has 'gone well', say heads
item.description: Millions have returned to school in England, with face masks and Covid tests for secondary pupils.

item.title: How could children make up for lost school time?
item.description: A massive task lies ahead for schools as they try to make up for teaching time lost during the pandemic.

item.title: The black children wrongly sent to 'special' schools in the 1970s
item.description: In the '60s and '70s, black children were wrongly sent to schools for the "educationally subnormal".

item.title: Covid: Parents worry about lost learning as schools reopen
item.description: Parents are confident about children returning to school but worry about catching up, says survey.

item.title: Parents not giving Covid test consent, warn heads
item.description: Heads say parents are not giving consent for Covid tests for children, ahead of going back to school.

item.title: A-Level results: Hackney twins head to Oxbridge with six A*s
item.description: Twin brothers from east London gain places at Oxford and Cambridge after achieving top A-level grades.

item.title: University clearing may be 'much more competitive' this year - Ucas boss
item.description: "It's still a good year for clearing," says the admissions service boss, ahead of results day next week.

item.title: Covid vaccine will not be compulsory for university lectures
item.description: Ministers are no longer considering making two doses mandatory for students in England, the BBC learns.

item.title: Exams likely to face more changes in 2022
item.description: Gavin Williamson says 2022 A-levels and GCSEs in England are likely to be modified for lost lessons.

item.title: Scottish exams body to be reformed amid grades row
item.description: The announcement comes amid criticism of the SQA over plans put in place to replace school exams this year.

item.title: Lectures staying online into autumn term
item.description: A student petition calls it "ridiculous" as some UK universities keep lectures online for next term.

item.title: Students feel like an 'afterthought' after university return date
item.description: They've been reacting to the news students won't be returning before 17 May.

item.title: Would universities call parents in a mental health crisis?
item.description: Bereaved parents call for universities to contact students' families to reduce risk of suicides.

item.title: What's the plan for students returning to uni?
item.description: Face-to-face courses cannot resume on campuses in England until at least 17 May.

item.title: Coronavirus: Should university students get a refund?
item.description: The pandemic has meant most students have been unable to go to lectures - so should they get a refund?

item.title: Turing Scheme: What is the Erasmus replacement?
item.description: What will Brexit mean for students in the UK wanting to work or study abroad?

item.title: Teachers' grades for cancelled A-level and GCSEs
item.description: A combination of mock exams, coursework and essays will be used to decide grades in England this year.

item.title: Coronavirus: The story of the big U-turn of the summer
item.description: The Department of Education and Ofqual will face public scrutiny to explain the exam confusion, the colossal U-turn and resignations. What went wrong?
